channel.title: Quick Question
channel.description: Hello, i was wondering if it was possible to split a switch statement over several classes. Ok, the best way i can explain it is to use a Private Server example. In Private servers, there is a void called useItemOnItem(int used, int usedOn). Is it possible to make several classes use this method(abstract class maybe?), and have it test each of those classes? This is incredibly hard to explain...

item.title: Quick Question
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

you just allocate 19 ‘spaces’ for instances of ‘Quest’ but you never ‘fill’ array with instances of Quest.

Read full topic

item.title: Quick Question
item.dc:creator: @Zero_Freeze ZeroFreeze
item.description:
@Zero_Freeze wrote:

I don’t think you quite understand the use of inheritance, interfaces etc.

You should read a tutorial about it here:
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/java/IandI/index.html

Read full topic

item.title: Quick Question
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Wow i feel like an idiot. As i probably should. Thanks everyone, it worked when i made an instance of each ‘Quest’.
Ok, i have another question. Would i be able to just create an instance of each ‘Quest’ in the interface? for example have something like:

package com.zymus.oraculum.quests;

import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

public interface Quest
    {
        public String getQuestName();
        public int getNumberOfSteps();
        public String getDescription(int Step);
        public boolean isMembers();

        public BlackKnightsFortress BKF = new BlackKnightsFortress();
    }

then implement the interface, so i don’t have to create an instance of each ‘Quest’ in QuestTest?

Read full topic

item.description:
@RLN wrote:

you didn’t initialize the Quests

Read full topic

item.title: Quick Question
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Thanks, I’ll try that with my actual code. The skills thing was just the easiest way i could think to explain it.

OK, so i tried it, using a different server example, and i get a NullPointerException thrown at me. I tried doing your method to get a quest name, like so:

import java.io.*;
import java.net.*;
import java.nio.*;
import java.nio.channels.*;
import com.zymus.oraculum.quests.*;
import com.zymus.oraculum.quests.freeplay.*;

public class QuestTest
    {
        public static void main(String[] args)
            {
                QuestTest Test = new QuestTest();
            }
        
        public QuestTest()
            {
                 try
                    {
                        Quest[] Quests = new Quest[19];
                        
                        if(Quests == null)
                            {
                                System.out.println("Quest[] Quests is null...");
                            }
                        
                        for(Quest Q : Quests)
                            {
                                if(Q == null)
                                    {
                                        System.out.println("Q is null...");
                                    }
                                    
                                System.out.println(Q.getQuestName());
                            }
                    }
                
                catch(Exception Error)
                    {
                        System.out.println(Error.getMessage());
                        Error.printStackTrace();
                    }
            }
    }

That’s the class i want to pull the info with. Here’s the interface:

package com.zymus.oraculum.quests;

import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

public interface Quest
    {
        public String getQuestName();
        public int getNumberOfSteps();
        public String getDescription(int Step);
        public boolean isMembers();
    }

Here’s a quest class:

package com.zymus.oraculum.quests.freeplay;

import java.io.*;
import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;
import com.zymus.oraculum.quests.*;

public class BlackKnightsFortress implements Quest
    {
        public String getQuestName()
            {
                return "Black Knights' Fortress";
            }
        
        public int getNumberOfSteps()
            {
                return 5;
            }
        
        public String getDescription(int Step)
            {
                switch(Step)
                    {
                        case 1:
                            return "test";
                        
                        case 2:
                            return "test 2";
                        
                        default:
                            System.out.println();
                        break;
                    }
                
                return null;
            }
        
        public boolean isMembers()
            {
                return false;
            }
    }

And here’s the error:

Q is null... null java.lang.NullPointerException at QuestTest.(QuestTest.java:32) at QuestTest.main(QuestTest.java:11)

What am i doing wrong?

Read full topic

item.title: Quick Question
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

make an interface

public interface ItemInterface { public void use(int used, int usedon); }

make some classes implement that, and make an array [tt]ItemInterface[] iint = new ItemInterface[somelength];[/tt]

then you go through the array and use it.

for(ItemInterface i : iint) { i.use(used, usedon); }

Read full topic
